awd_titl_txt: CCRI: MEDIUM: Collaborative Research: Community Platforms for Safe, Agile, and Coordinated Autonomy
awd_abstract_narration:
F1/10 is a shared, open-sourced infrastructure for the development and validation of new approaches to autonomous perception, planning, control and coordination. This community platform will facilitate autonomous system research, education and bench-marking through the creation of a new class of high-performance autonomous racing cars, that are 1/10th the size of a real (Formula 1) car and can reach a top speed of 50mph. The goal is to enable a wide range of experimental research and education in Safe, Secure, Coordinated and Efficient Autonomy. Much of today's research on Autonomous vehicles (AVs) is limited to experimentation on expensive commercial vehicles that require large teams with diverse skills and power-hungry platforms. Testing the limits of safety and performance on such vehicles is costly and hazardous. It is also outside the reach of most academic departments and research groups. Furthermore, little research has been devoted to the development of safety benchmarks and infrastructure for certifying autonomous systems, guaranteeing the safety of data-driven decision making, power-efficient perception and control for efficient autonomy, active coordinated safety for large vehicle fleets, and cyber-physical security of autonomous vehicles. All of these are fundamental requirements on the road to achieving the social benefits of autonomous vehicles, and autonomous systems more generally. F1/10 provides rapid prototyping hardware, software and algorithmic platforms, with full documentation and community support for research and development of future autonomous systems. 

Autonomous vehicles are emerging as integral components of the US economy, and in the future, they may be at the heart of the national economy's competitiveness in transportation and logistics. Enabling such a transformation requires building reliably safe and efficient autonomous vehicles and the contributions of a very diverse community of researchers from engineering, human factors and computer science. The project's intellectual merit resides in the design and deployment of scaled autonomous cars that are affordable, safe to experiment with, easy to customize, can be shared widely, and that can support a wide range of necessary research in autonomous vehicles. This project's broader goal is to stimulate and accelerate cross-disciplinary research in autonomous vehicle safety and efficiency, at a time when such work is urgently needed. This project will enable researchers in autonomous hardware, safety, security, and traffic to produce high-confidence autonomous systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Autonomous control and decision systems are forming the basis for significant pieces of our nation’s critical infrastructure. In particular, Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) present direct and urgent safety-critical challenges. About 10 years ago, the self-driving car industry made rosy predictions on widespread adoption of the technology by 2020; however, this has not come to pass due, in large part, to concerns about safety and robustness of the technology while operating in complex scenarios and the underestimation of the true difficulty of fielding robust perception and control systems in the real world. Developing safe and trustworthy Autonomous Intelligent Cyber-Physical Systems (AI-CPS) requires a major collaborative approach unifying various stakeholders including developers of AI-CPS, end users, regulators and government agencies, researchers, etc.

To address these concerns, over the past several years, the PIs have developed RoboRacer  (formerly F1Tenth) supporting a systematic methodology for the design, testing, and deployment of AI-CPS. RoboRacer currently encompasses: (i) an open-source autonomy stack which operates on autonomous vehicles of different scales, (ii) an education curriculum for next-generation autonomous systems engineers, (iii) community engagement through a series of annual international autonomous racing competitions, (iv) workshops, tutorials along with K-12 outreach and industry engagement. RoboRacer is used in 90+ universities worldwide, hosted 24 international competitions, has 2400+ active members and has resulted in over 68 publications by the community.

The RoboRacer project began in Fall 2017 at the University of Pennsylvania as F1Tenth, with the aim of providing a clear yet extensible framework for development, testing and training machine learning-based algorithms for autonomous systems. Following the initial release of the modular rule-based perception, planning and control stack with a high-fidelity simulator, the learning-based algorithms for localization, motion planning, and control development culminated in 2024 with the release of RoboRacer 2.0, adding adaptive control barrier functions, localization using invertible neural networks, imitation learning from multiple imperfect experts, online safe reinforcement learning, distributionally robust online adaptation via offline population synthesis, etc. enabling safe and high-performance autonomous driving in across multiple platform scales. Since then, the AV stack has been stable, and the next release of RoboRacer will add cloud-based simulation with high-fidelity vehicle dynamics, sensors and driving environments. This simulator has facilitated online racing competitions with 57+ teams.

RoboRacer was publicly released as open source in October 2018 on GitHub. Since then, it has been regularly updated and maintained, and has had many users and a small but growing community of developers. Current relevant statistics from GitHub include: 22 developers, over 1,535 forks (not counting our direct collaborators), and 851 stars, spanning academia and industry. 

RoboRacer.AI has a strong open-source foundation enabling dependable societal-scale applications through safe and high-performance AI-CPS. The PIs have a strong track record of robotics innovation in industry and education, developing new tools and curriculum for design of cyber-physical systems, formal methods, and control systems. This project will have a very strong impact on the adoption of learning-enabled machine perception, motion planning and adaptive control for AI-CPS design across home and industrial robotics, multi-agent dynamic games, and electric vehicle fleets.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Rahul Mangharam

Developing safe and trustworthy Autonomous Intelligent Cyber-Physical Systems (AI-CPS) requires a major collaborative approach unifying various stakeholders including developers of AI-CPS, end users, regulators and government agencies, researchers, etc.


To address these concerns, over the past several years, the PIs have developed RoboRacer (formerly F1Tenth) supporting a systematic methodology for the design, testing, and deployment of AI-CPS.
